articles.title: EVENTS CALENDAR
articles.summary: This document is an events calendar outlining upcoming activities for November and early December. It includes indoor star parties, general meetings with notable speakers such as Nick Vaivodica from the Voyager and Galileo projects, a board meeting, and an observing event at Fremont Peak. These events take place at various locations including Los Gatos and the University of Santa Clara.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: Don Machholz's "Comet Comments" reports on the recent discovery of three new comets and the recovery of two previously known ones within the past month. The article details five specific comets—Periodic Comet Schaumasse (1984m), Periodic Comet Kowal-Mrkos (1984n), Comet Meier (1984o), Periodic Comet Tsuchinshan (1984p), and Comet Shoemaker (1984q)—providing their discovery/recovery details, magnitudes, and visibility prospects. Notably, Periodic Comet Schaumasse is mentioned as potentially visible to amateur astronomers.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides ephemerides for three comets—Comet Austin (1984i), Periodic Comet Schaumasse (1984m), and Periodic Comet Arend-Rigaux (1984k)—detailing their celestial coordinates (R.A., Dec.), elongation, and visual magnitude from late October to early December 1984. It includes brief observational notes, indicating Comet Austin is fading but visible all night, Comet Schaumasse is brightening in the morning sky, and Comet Arend-Rigaux will be brightest in early December.

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES
articles.summary: Steve Gottlieb compares the visual performance of 8-inch and 13-inch telescopes for observing deep-sky objects like globular clusters and galaxies. He notes that while an 8-inch can resolve many globulars and reveal hundreds of galaxies as faint blurs, a 13-inch aperture significantly enhances detail, resolving globular cores and revealing intricate spiral arm structures in numerous galaxies. The article concludes that larger apertures provide more stunning views and are essential for detailed galaxy structure, while also including a brief update on Halley's Comet.

articles.title: DAYLIGHT OBSERVATIONS OF DOUBLE STARS BY: DR. A. B. GREGORY
articles.summary: Dr. A. B. Gregory contends that observing and splitting double stars can be surprisingly easier and yield sharper views during daylight hours, specifically between sunset and sunrise. He attributes this to the absence of glare, diffraction rings, and reduced contrast compared to nighttime observations. Examples like Castor and Epsilon Bootis (Izar) demonstrate that even challenging doubles can be resolved more readily, often at lower magnifications, once the star is successfully located.

articles.title: LOW MAGNITUDE SPLITTING
articles.summary: This article describes an amateur astronomer's successful observations of low-magnitude double stars during daylight hours, including challenging splits such as a magnitude 13 companion of Procyon. The author utilized a 5-inch aperture telescope with specific filters and highlighted the advanced observing skills required for finding and accurately splitting these systems. The piece encourages other amateur astronomers to experiment with similar observations to test their own limits and proficiency.

articles.title: KNOW YOUR SIDEREAL TIME
articles.summary: This article underscores the essential role of sidereal time for amateur astronomers to accurately locate celestial objects visible from their specific location. It provides instructions on adjusting published sidereal time charts based on local mean time and one's geographical position relative to the time zone meridian. The piece also briefly mentions the creation of custom sidereal watches and points out a specific sidereal time anomaly for the year 1972.

articles.title: POINTING YOUR CELESTRON
articles.summary: The article describes a method for accurately pointing a Celestron telescope using sidereal time and a custom-added right ascension pointer, particularly for locating celestial objects during daylight hours. It details how to set up and use the sidereal time pointer and calculates hour angle. Practical tips for daytime observation include stopping down the aperture with a diaphragm, using long focal length eyepieces, and pre-focusing the telescope.

articles.title: EDITORS NOTE:
articles.summary: This editor's note refers to an article by Dr. Gregory on daylight observations, originally published in the October 1972 issue of Celestron Techniques. The editor expresses interest in hearing from members who have attempted similar observations.

articles.title: A PHOTOGRAPHIC MAP OF THE HEAVENS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz undertook a multi-month project to create a photographic map of the night sky, dividing the observable heavens into 78 sections. Using a 35mm SLR camera and simple equipment, he captured color slides showing stars down to eighth magnitude. The endeavor, though not intended for specific use, proved to be a valuable learning experience in astrophotography and sky mapping.

articles.title: BY ROBERT FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article details two space shuttle missions: Challenger's successful Mission 41-G, which included the first female spacewalk, deployment of the ERBS satellite, and use of SIR-B radar for geological studies and water detection. It also previews the upcoming Discovery Mission 51-A, outlining its crew and objectives, which primarily involve the recovery of the Palapa B-2 and Westar 6 communication satellites, alongside various scientific experiments.

articles.title: ATM coatings
articles.summary: The document advertises a service for aluminum and silicon monoxide coatings for telescope mirrors, listing prices for various mirror sizes and services like old coating removal. Additionally, it presents several news updates from the astronomy and space sector, including cosmonauts ending a record stay on Salyut 7, a potential Galileo flyby of asteroid Amphitrite, completion of the Space Telescope's optical assembly, EOSAT's selection to operate LANDSAT spacecraft, and the completion of a 30-inch Medlock amateur telescope mirror.

articles.title: ASTRO MART
articles.summary: This 'Astro Mart' section features classified listings for astronomy equipment, including parts for a 6" reflector and a 300mm f/5.6 Celestron telescope, both available for sale with contact details provided. Additionally, it announces that the club's 14" Dobson telescope is available for members to use by contacting David York.
